item.title: About
item.description:
What I do

Shortly after graduating with my PhD from MIT, I took off to Tokyo, Japan thanks to a fellowship from the Japanese Society for the Promotion of Science. I am now working in the lab of Kenya Honda on a couple of projects to discern the molecular bases for protective effects of bacteria on their hosts. Now, and during my PhD, I focus on a few main questions:

  • How do bacteria move through the environment, and what are the environmental cues that allow microorganisms to distinguish hospitable from inhospitable environments?
  • What environmental features ensure the growth, maintenance, and persistent colonization of microorganisms introduced into new ecosystems? That is, what constraints should we consider when constructing a microbial niche?
  • What are the consequences of microbial physiological activities on their environments and how do these feedback into microbial physiology?

What I care about

Animals have always been an important part of my life, and I have a lot of compassion and empathy for them. I spend a lot of time thinking about animal welfare and more broadly welfare and equitability for the disenfranchised. On this front, I volunteer with animal rights organizations and look for ways to encourage people to adopt more compassionate diets.

item.title: On Science
item.description:
Microbial Ecology

Thinking on the scale of microorganisms can be really challenging as a macroorganism. While the intuition and approaches developed for macroecology may have relevance in microbial ecosytems, in many ways, I think it is misleading to think about microbial ecology as a miniature version of macrobial ecology.

Undergraduate education in bioprocess engineering emphasizes scaling up bench-scale technologies to industrial scale fermentations. Unfortunately, scale-up is a nontrivial process, particularly for cell culture, as behaviors and physiology of cells at the lab scale often completely change in >1000 L reactors. In a similar way, the behavior of microorganisms on small scales, even when in isolation, is not as predictable as simply scaling down observations from bulk culture growth.

I chose to do a PhD in biological engineering because I wanted to develop new tools to study microorganisms and microbial ecology that do not rely on extrapolation of intuitions from macroscale biological processes. In order to do so, I think it is important to abandon assumptions about how things are going to work, and in a sense, meet the microbes where they’re at. To me, this mentality requires new approaches: ways of identifying microbial populations, predicting how microorganisms respond to perturbations, and how isogenic microbial populations differentiate in time and space in response to microscale changes in their environments.
